talk.start.para: âI am particularly interested in this bill, the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1997, as I chair the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties where issues such as the Teoh case and the government's response to this difficulty come up almost every time we meet in a general and sometimes abstract sense. In that case, a court decision had it that, even where the terms of a treaty have not been incorporated into Australian law, a legitimate expectation arises that agencies of government will not act contrary to the terms of the treaty. The judgment made plain that this legitimate expectation can be set aside by a legislative indication to the contraryâhence, this bill going through.

speech.para: The language of the decision the court handed down is interesting because it uses the phrase `agencies will not act contrary to the terms of the treaty'. This is no surprise because what is not well understood about the treaty making process is that no legal obligation arises for the executive of a government taking part in the negotiations of a treaty. However, once the treaty is signed and before ratification, it is widely thought that it does not bind the country so we do not have to worry about it. That is not entirely so, because there is another treaty, the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties, which gives the rules according to which treaties are to be interpreted. One of the basic articles of that treaty says that once a party has signed a treaty, and even before ratification, it is obliged not to act in a way contrary to the objectives of that treaty. In a sense, there is a hybrid obligation already arisen on a government once a treaty is signed.

This rarely understood provision has led to an interesting decision being made this week by the government parties. It is a matter of public record that, henceforth, before a coalition government signs a treatyâthat is, at the end of the negotiation process but before the treaty is signedâthese treaties will be submitted to the government party room for scrutiny by the backbench. This is a profound change in practice and it gives members of the government parties a very valuable opportunity to comment, criticise, object to or, of course, support a proposed treaty before that obligation arises under the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties and well before the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties examines the text of the treaty before ratification.

What Teoh was really all about was a bizarre attempt by the judiciary, or one aspect of it, to `legal creep'âyou might describe it in that sense. People talk about `mission creep' in peacekeeping efforts abroad. On first glance it might seem a reasonable chain of logic in that a government signs a treaty and there is this obligation under the Vienna convention and, therefore, the agencies of government should act in a way that is not contrary to the terms of the treaty. This is, in effect, sneaking around the legislature and ignoring the role of this parliament, and that is what we are about stopping.

There are two big questions in treaty making in Australia's case. The first is the question of state or local government inconsistency with a treaty that has been signed by the national government. This happens, of course, from time to time. The mandatory sentencing controversy was an example of that. I might also point out that one of the local governments in Sydney that proposes a code of practice to regulate the establishment of brothelsâthat is, South Sydney Councilâmay well be in violation of article 6 of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Article 6 says that state partiesâthat is the Commonwealth governmentâshall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women. So if a local government deliberately sets out to regulate or encourage the establishment of brothels for perfectly reasonable purposesâfor instance, you do not want them next to schools, hospitals, churches or whateverâthen that ordinance of the local government is in breach of this treaty. And the question arises: what will the Commonwealth gov-ernment do about that? That is not something that I am going to go into in any further detail today, but I do flag it as something that is going to happen from time to time in the future. Many of the environ-mental treatiesâsome of which I regard, frankly, as quite poisonousâcould well cause the same sorts of inconsistencies with local governments in Australia.

The other grand question that faces this countryâand it is a very important one in terms of our trading interestsâis how we go about maintaining the integrity of the WTO rules. World Trade Organisation rules establish a rules based structure for international trade. This is under threat from what you could describe as the global antiprivate enterprise movementâgreens, neopagans or whatever you want to call themâand certain protectionist trading groups such as the European Union and, indeed, some governments in our part of the world, in Asia, who seek to protect their domestic agricultural interests from imports from Australia. They use an interesting phrase called the precautionary principle. The adoption of this principle in treaties and its creep in scope has the potential to do enormous damage to Australian trading interests. It is something that we must always be aware of and do what we can to stop it.

It is interesting that the people who are complaining the loudest about the MAI, the Multilateral Agreement on Investmentâwhich was a draft textâcomplain that it really took away Australia's sovereignty, that it was too vaguely drafted and that it could affect state and local governments. These are often the same people who push so hard for this precautionary principle. The WTO rules have two essential elements that we must do our best to protect. The first is that the use of trade sanctions to impose domestic policies extraterritoriallyâwhether they are some sort of economic policy such as trying to protect the producers of a certain good or even some kind of social policyâis illegal. Secondly, any import ban must be justified on internationally recognised scientific grounds. That is to say, if you want to ban the importation of something and you are challenged under WTO rules, you have to prove, using internationally recognised scientific standards, that the importation of those things would be dangerous on health grounds, or that sort of thing.

There are a number of international agreements that already allow the use of trade sanctions against non-consenting third parties. This is also a particularly dangerous thing because it sets up two incompatible systems of international lawâthat is, you have the WTO rules, the burden of proof being on the person who seeks to ban something to prove that the ban is justified; yet there is another developing set of international laws whereby the burden of proof is placed on the potential exporter of something. This appears in various forms. At the WTO talks in Seattle, where there was so much violence on the streets, behind all the smoke and loud noise, the United States and Europe were arguing for linkage between environmental and labour standards and the trade rulesâthat is, they were trying to incorporate into the WTO system the ability for themselves as governments to use spurious environmental complaints or complaints about labour standards in other countries, particularly the People's Republic of China, in order to be able to stop the importation of goods to protect their own domestic interests. Happily, this was opposed by most of the other parties there, including Australia of course, and the meeting collapsed in disagreement.

One more recent international agreement in which this dangerous notion of the precautionary principle is being pushed so hard is what is known as the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety, under the UN Convention on Biodiversity, to which Australia is a party. This also seeks to legitimise trade sanctions against non-consenting third parties. It is interesting that, under this protocol, any disputes about the importation of an LMO, a living modified organismâbecause it deals with gene technologyâgo not to the WTO but to the ICJ, or even to an arbitrator appointed by the United Nations Secretary-General. So you can see that it clearly seeks to supplant the WTO process.

I should say a little more about the precautionary principle. The best way of illuminating how dangerous it can be, I suppose, is to quote from the gene technology section on the web site of Greenpeace International. There is an article published there about the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety. It says:

quote.para: The battle was won for the precautionary principle to be the basis for decision-making on transboundary movements of all living modified organisms, including for commodities.

speech.para: And that goes directly to Australia's national interest. They also quote from articles 10(6) and 11(6) as follows:

quote.para: Lack of scientific certainty due to insufficient relevant scientific information and knowledge regarding the extent of the potential adverse effects of a living modified organism on the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity in the Party of import, taking also into account risks to human health, shall not prevent that Party from taking a decision, as appropriate, with regard to the import of the living modified organism in question as referred to in paragraph 3 above, in order to avoid or minimize such potential adverse effects.

speech.para: In essence that means that, if somebody denounces a certain product that has somewhere in it some modified gene technology, whether it is food or crop seed, that will give the party of import, as they are calledâfor that, you can read the European Union and maybe Japan, Korea and other countries that, from time to time, seek to protect agriculture in their nationâthe grounds on which they can ban the import of that LMO, and then the burden of proof shifts to the exporter to prove that it is not dangerous. In a sense, in this kind of case Australia would be required to prove that what we were trying to do is not dangerousâto prove a negative. In the case of these LMOs, they will say, `You'll need time to prove that it is not dangerous.' That might be 10 or 20 years. So in effect you have handed carte blanche over to a protectionist government in another country to inflict damage on Australia via something like the Cartagena Protocol, which is being negotiated ostensibly on environmental grounds but which will be manipulated by protectionist governments to use it for their own domestic political purposes.

The European Union is probably the chief offender when it comes to governments trying to push this precautionary principle as far as possible. On 2 February this year the European Union, I suppose via the commission, issued a communication giving guidance to its members on how to act on the precautionary principle:

quote.para: The appropriate response in a given situation is thus the result of a political decision, a function of the risk that is "acceptable" to the society on which it is imposed.

speech.para: There it is in plain language: it is the result of a political decision. The agenda of these peopleâwhether it be Greenpeace, the EU or whoever else among this group of organised political folk trying to push thisâis to try to introduce a political decision that gives grounds to ban imports of agriculture. That is what this is all about. By denouncing something as dangerous, and by mounting an effective publicity campaign and placing the burden of proof on the accusedâthat is, the exporterâthese people effectively hand power over to any organised political group, and they emasculate elected legislatures such as ours. They inflict terrible damage on the rule of lawâwhether it be domestic or international, in the case of the WTOâand the judicial institutions that buttress a truly civilised society.

For people who are interested in pursuing this a little further, I recommend they go to the trade negotiations part of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's web site and read some of the descriptions about how the negotiations of the Cartagena Protocol have been going for the last few years. People will see that, time and time again, there have been attempts by the EU or other protectionist governments or groups of governments to include in the text of this agreement this precautionary principle, and that they have tried to get it established by agreementâI think surreptitiouslyâthat multinational environment agreements, MEAs, should not be subordinate to the WTO rules. There is a terrific argument about the relationship between environmental agreements like the Cartagena Protocol and the WTO rules. One of the four consensus elements that all people agreed to at the beginning of this negotiation, I think quite mistakenly, was that the protocol and other international agreementsâfor that, you can read the WTO rulesâare of equal status and that trade and environment agreements and policies should be mutually supportive. `Mutually supportive' is very vague language. Interestingly, it is on the Greenpeace web site. They say exactly that. The language in one paragraph reads:

quote.para: ... recognises that trade and environmental agreements should be mutually supportive with a view to achieving sustainable development.

speech.para: From Greenpeace's point of view, `mutually supportive' means that the reversal of the burden of proofâthis precautionary principleâis not of equal status with the rules under the WTO but in fact becomes paramount to it. They will use this in the future to make it all the more difficult for Australia and other agricultural countries to try to get that level playing field in trade. It is a very dangerous thing.

They are also trying to introduce the precautionary principle directly into the codex alimentarius, which is a body of rules under the GATT-WTO system. They seek to subvert the whole structure of it. It is something that I do not think enough people in Australia are awake to. I know that all of the governmentâfrom the backbench to the cabinet ministersâare busy, but we ought to take things a little slower from time to time and examine some of these things in more detail. What can appear quite innocent in one area of policyâenvironmental protection, which is a perfectly reasonable sort of thingâwill be used as a precedent to inflict terrible damage on Australia in another area of policy, and that is trade. Had the precautionary principle been on foot in the first two decades of this century, they would have banned the development and sale of the internal combustion engine. They would not have allowed us to drive and sell cars because, `We do not know what damage emissions from cars can do to the environment, so let's not produce them, drive them, sell them or whatever.' They are against science and they should be denounced.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1999. As a member representing an electorate in Sydney's south-west comprising large numbers of newly arrived residents, I have something of a vested interest in the procedures followed by officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Members dealing with a large volume of immigration matters know that the programs providing for permanent settlement in this country are limited and that, for every shonky case that gets through the net, a genuine and useful migrant misses out. Members would also be aware that the circumstances surrounding every application for residence is different and that many tears are shed at the reception counters of electorate offices and in the confines of a member's office when dealing with individuals who have witnessed or experienced evil in the shape of war or inhumanity in its various forms. This excess of demand over the available places we have in our immigration programs is more acutely felt by DIMA officers. They are the selection panel, and we are asking them to give us the best on the one hand and the most deserving on the other.

speech.para: Illegals seeking a change in status, in my experience, get a reasonably fair deal under the current assessment methods. It is not a scientifically precise area. Many people tell the most appalling lies to stay here and avail themselves of every level of their appeal rights. I am not convinced that they use those rights to genuinely test the merits of their case. Many consider the exploitation of those rights as simply a strategy to prolong their stay. Because of bridging visas and the time taken in the appeal processes, many of those who win the right of residence have already formed the view that Australian society and its institutions are there to be got around and that straightforward, open and honest dealings with the government get you nowhere. It is a pity that the system itself is promoting the values we find among the tax avoiders and evaders who view the benefits of society like health, education and defence as things only mugs put anything towards. The reason we are going to have a GST is that tax cheating is so entrenched that the only way the Howard government can deal with it is by penalising everyone, but especially the mugs who always pay their fair share of tax.

The operators have been working over the immigration laws of this country so that what you might expect to be a carefully considered decision depends on whether you got it from the highest court in the land. Our audience here, we should remember, are not citizens. We should therefore make the rules as clear and simple as possible. It is anything but helpful to intending illegal migrants to show them a bag full of shades of opinion. The Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1999 provides as much a clear signal as anything else. This bill removes unintended consequences resulting from the Teoh decision, especially with regard to immigration but generally across the whole board. It has been a long time in the making, and the Labor Party has given it a great deal of thought. It is, with regret, the easiest and clearest route to take. While this might stir debate about human rights, about our commitment to international conventions, about how fair dinkum we might seem to the international community and about the more creative decisions of the High Court, the fact is that Teohâand we have to remember thisâwas not an Australian citizen. He had been convicted of an extremely serious offence and was not welcome in Australia. Any decision maker in immigration would have had no doubt that deportation was consequential. Indeed, most reasonable Australians would have a legitimate expectation that nothing less than prison and subsequent deportation would result if a non-national were convicted of running hard drugs into our country.

I think decision makers, dispassionate as they might try to be, ask themselves all the time: Is this fair? Is this right? And often find themselves saying no and no, time and again but still approve an application because they are bound to implementing the legislation, not its spirit. If it is poorly constructed legislation it comes back to the parliament for repair. We need to keep migration decisions straight up and down. The practicality of having decision makers taking into account more than the legislation provides logically extends to consulting the full range of holy texts in making a determination. Clearly, the process should, and currently does, provide for sufficient review rights for an adverse outcome to be overturned. Mr Teoh, a Malaysian national, exercised those rights and he won. The issues as to whether or not he had a genuine expectation on the rights of his children, whether executive ratification of conventions has the same force as laws passed by the parliament, whether ratification really takes effect when enabling legislation is passed, whether ratification adds to the body of common law, whether procedural fairness is involved or whether the High Court has been too adventurous did not have much to do with the outcome that an undesirable got through the net; it was unintended.

Our amendments are aimed at greater clarity to ensure there is no conflict between ratifying an international convention and making a domestic decision about how we manage our affairs in the interests of all residents, all citizens. Clarity is also owed to the international community, and that is an important part of the opposition's amendments. As it stands, the Teoh doctrine could see more undesirables taking the place of potentially good law-abiding citizens of tomorrow. We do not want that, the international community does not expect that and it is simply not fair, as anyone in my electorate of Fowler will tell you regardless of their country of birth.

I can remember when Australia was moving to ratify the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Many would recall there was a major outcry along the lines that parents would no longer have control of their children. Those fears have not been realised, but the Teoh case provides grounds for nervousness, especially among those of us who accused the opponents of ratification of taking too narrow a legal view of a document, the intent of which was pure and the provisions of which would need to be incorporated into Australian law before they actually meant anything. There was also considerable debate about whether Australian laws, particularly state welfare laws, complied with the convention. When we ratified the convention in 1990 it was with a reservation about children with parents in jail. Nobody saw Teoh coming. Most of the arguments distinguished between international law and Australian or domestic law and whether Australian laws fully complied with the obligations attached to the convention. Most of those in the debate had common agreement with the general objectives in the convention which are directed against the exploitation of children and their adequate representation in legal proceedings.

Elements in the legal industry are alarmed at what they see as a curtailment of judicial review of decision making. I can appreciate that, but the situation is fluid. It is not like having the chief magistrate in your pocket, on a secret contract or bound to impose mandatory sentences. The Teoh case has not caused major upheavals in administrative law, although we have different estimates of just how many cases have been affected. The parliament has an obligation to clarify the issue for decision makers as well as for likely appellants. This bill does that. It does not signal a war with the High Court, as some in the legal industry would have people believe. The fact is that the High Court can make decisions which are not aligned to the intentions of the parliament or the people it represents. A bill of rights might better state this. We might also look at the courts imposing fines on government agencies where wrong administrative decisions have been made. But we are dealing with the world as it is today and the parliament has to call the shots. We are the ones to answer to our citizens, whereas the courts do not enter into any discussion yet they change laws by their decisions. It is a proper role for parliament to consider those changes and make corrections to fit a world full of angles and opportunities. Look at the Mabo decision: it generated debate, it brought the issue into the parliament and the ownership of the issue was rightly given to the people. As far as tensions between the courts and the parliament are concerned, the whole process has been orderly. As far as the Teoh case goes, decision makers in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs now have guidelines emphasising the interests of any children who might be affected in considering the deportation of non-citizens. So, effectively, the High Court has reached out and touched the DIMA decision makers. But the fact remains that, with something close to a thousand treaties, decision makers cannot be expected to consider everything. The courts too are wide open for a range of appeals based on completely outrageous technical arguments drawn from treaties.

What is also critical is that the executive, in ratifying a convention, might be effectively making laws. That is not what democracy is about. It is a dangerous path and hardly what citizens have been led to expect. If that were the case, those people fearful of world government or concerned that treaties were part of an international conspiracy would be justified. The Teoh decision has great potential to help in fuelling the notion, if not the reality, that we are no longer a sovereign state. We want to say to those people that adopting a convention, far from undermining our status as an independent nation, actually assures the rest of the world that we are a fully mature participant in the affairs of the world. We have many such treaties. They do not reduce us; they enhance our world citizenship. These treaties have served us well in the shaping of our domestic law. That is important and should be expressly stated in this legislation. Courts can and do look at conventions and treaties when guidance is required, and the common law provides a means of ensuring the intentions of international instruments take their place in judgments. I have dealt with more immigration cases than you can poke a stick at. I have never come across a legitimate expectation that our ratification of the Convention on the Rights of the Child has any bearing on a decision. Frankly, given the pressure facing the department in Australia's migrant intake, the only legitimate expectation any intending migrant can have is that the answer is likely to be no. I always tell their families how reasonable their expectations should be and that I will get them an answer within the legislative framework, not an international convention. And what of Mr Teoh? I understand he is now a resident of Western Australia, a state which does not deserve him.

talk.start.para: âIt gives me pleasure to speak in this debate today and I note the contributions which have been made by previous speakers. The Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1999, as others have said, seeks to overrule the principle established by the High Court in the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v. Teohâthe Teoh caseâthat when the executive enters into an international agreement a legitimate expectation arises that the executive will act in accordance with the provisions of that agreement. Others have made the substance of this legislation very clear, but for a moment I want to go to some of the issues. In particular I want to talk about expectations the community might have of governments in relation to international obligations which they may freely enter into. This particular piece of legislation has been under scrutiny by this parliament for a great period of time. It was the subject of a Senate inquiry and from that there was a minority report under the authorship of Senators Nick Bolkus and Jim McKiernan. In their contribution they made the following observation:

quote.para: ... experience demonstrates that Teoh is only likely to have limited application. For example, in many circumstances where an international obligation could be pleaded as giving rise to a legitimate expectation, it could also be pleaded that the consideration referred to would be a relevant consideration such that a failure to consider it would render the decision defective. Accordingly, aggrieved parties are much more likely to rely upon, and succeed with, this more substantive and recognised basis to challenge a decision.

speech.para: They then go through and make an assessment of the limited impact of Teoh. They say:

quote.para: Given the limited practical impact of Teoh, and the issues of principle involved, Labor believes that it is not now necessary, in the interests of effective administrative decision making, to expressly set aside the possibility of such legitimate expectations being created, but that it is necessary to reaffirm that an international treaty cannot have legal effect in Australian domestic law unless it is expressly incorporated by legislation, or its substance is incorporated, in whole or in part by the operation of the common law.

speech.para: They foreshadow that Labor would amend the 1997 bill to this effect and that the amendments would prove a means of ensuring that administrative decision makers are aware of their legal obligations. The nature of these amendments is thus here. They said:

quote.para: Accordingly, Labor will be amending the Bill to ensure that it affirms the principle that:

... an international instrument (even though binding in international law on Australia) affects administrative decisions and procedures under domestic law only to the extent either that the instrument has the force of domestic law under an enactment or its substance in whole or in part has effect by the operation of the common law.

speech.para: That is the content of the opposition amendment, and it is something which I am pleased to support. In the course of the discussion this morning, I noted in particular the reference which was made to the obligation that we have as a community to acknowledge our responsibilities under international law and to acknowledge our responsibilities under United Nations conventions. I want to refer to one of those conventions today, and that is the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. This convention prohibits racial discrimination and provides for equality before the law, regardless of race, colour or national or ethnic origin. Australia enacted the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975 to give effect to the convention domesticallyâa convention which was signed, I might say, by the then Prime Minister, Gough Whitlam, in that same year.

Australia has obligations under the convention and is required to report every two years to the CERD committee on additional measures it has adopted to implement the convention. The CERD committee may make recommendations on the basis of these reports. You will know, Madam Deputy Speaker, that in August 1988 the CERD committee made an early-warning, urgent action decision in respect of the Australian government. The committee requested information on changes to the Native Title Act 1993, changes in other aspects of the land rights policy and in the functions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. It wanted to examine whether any such changes were compatible with the government's obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. Australia is the first stable Western democracy to have been issued with a `Please explain'. The government responded to the early warning with a report released in late January 1999, and the government was present during the deliberations of the CERD committee.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you may recall that a number of public statements were made by prominent Australians in relation to the CERD findings, and you may also recall that the Prime Minister hosted a luncheon in honour of Mr Kofi Annan, the UN Secretary-General. During that luncheon on 21 February 2000, the Prime Minister made the following observations which refer in part to Australia's commitment in East Timor:

quote.para: But it was an operation under ultimately your leadership Mr Secretary General and it was an operation under the auspices of the United Nations; a body with whom we have had a very long association, a body with which Australia continues to make a major contribution. Not only in terms of political support but also in terms of resources and the contribution to East Timor for example by the year 2003, will represent about three billion dollars by the people of Australia.

speech.para: He goes on to say:

quote.para: I have valued very much my association with you and the great body over which you preside.

speech.para: You can imagine, then, how I amazed I was when I noted the press release from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer, dated 30 March 2000, in which the foreign affairs minister says:

quote.para: The Federal Government will undertake a whole-of-government review of the operation of the United Nations treaty committee system as it affects Australia.

speech.para: He then referred to the CERD committee. He said:

quote.para: In this context, the Government was appalled at the blatantly political and partisan approach taken by the UN's Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination ... when it examined Australia's periodic reports in Geneva last week.

speech.para: He is referring to the ones I spoke about earlier. He goes on:

quote.para: The Committee's observations are little more than a polemical attack on the Government' indigenous policies.

speech.para: What happened in this instance was that the Australian government used all its resources to try to persuade a United Nations properly constituted committee to have a different view than that which it had ascribed to in its formal hearings and to which it had asked the Australian government to respond. So, following the statement by the Prime Minister that he respected very much Australia's association with the United Nations, the Minister for Foreign Affairs then chose to attack one of its committees because of what it said about Australia, because the Australian government was offended by its words.

Nothing was done, however, when another international treaty was a matter of grave discussion. You will recall, Madam Deputy Speaker, that that related to salmon and the World Trade Organisation. It is very interesting that here we have got a proposition about trade and, because of the way in which the World Trade Organisation is structured, the Australian government felt it necessary, against the wishes of the people of Tasmania and the Tasmanian government, to abide by a determination of that organisation, even though the community of Tasmania, and the salmon industry in particular, have made it abundantly clear to the government what they thought of its position. Yet we had the Australian government accepting the will of the World Trade Organisation and, in a sense, overriding the wishes of the people of Tasmania. On the other hand, we have a committee properly constituted under the United Nations which makes very serious observations about the way in which Australia has treated its obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and, because it does not like the findings, the Australian government pillories the committee members, the structure of the committee and the way in which the committee has made its deliberations.

It is worth while contemplating just for a moment what Australia's obligations are under this convention. CERD outlines internationally agreed minimum standards of behaviour which states undertake to observe by ratifying the convention. Article 2 of the convention places positive obligations on the states not to discriminate and to prevent others within their jurisdictions from discriminating. Article 5 requires that, in accordance with this principle, states guarantee the right of everyone to equality before the law, including in relation to political rights, the right to own property individually or communally, the right to inherit and the right to equal participation in cultural activities. The CERD committee has recognised that racially discriminatory practices are often systemic and long term in effect. Consequently, states have obligations to ensure that the effects of past discrimination are not continued into the future and to address the continued inequality of marginalised groups. Of course, that has particular resonance here in Australia. CERD places obligations on states to take all appropriate means to combat and eliminate discrimination against indigenous peoples and has called on states to: (a) recognise and respect indigenous distinct culture, history, language and way of life as an enrichment of the state's cultural identity and to promote its preservation; (b) ensure that members of indigenous peoples are free and equal in dignity and rights and free from any discrimination, and in particular that based on indigenous identity; (c) provide indigenous peoples with conditions allowing sustainable economic and social development compatible with their cultural characteristics; (d) ensure that members of indigenous peoples have equal rights in respect of effective participation in public life and that no decisions directly relating to their rights and interests are taken without their informed consent; and (e) ensure that indigenous communities can exercise their rights to practise and revitalise their cultural traditions and customs and preserve and practise their languages.

What this committee did was to actually look at a piece of Australian law and assess whether or not that law met Australia's obligations under these conventions. This matter has been the subject of an inquiry by the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, which is looking at this issue and will come down with a report within the next month. With the Teoh case we have ensured that decisions are properly taken by governments and that our sovereignty is not eroded. We have accepted our obligations in one case in the World Trade Organisation. We have abided by the rules involved.

In the case of the Racial Discrimination Act, we have passed a piece of legislation which specifically accords with the requirements of this United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. So we have actually enacted laws in this country to ensure that we abide as far as we possibly can by this convention. We are put under the spotlight of the CERD committee's scrutiny and, because the government is offended by the findings of this committee and the submissions which have been made to that committee by organisations such as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the government takes the extraordinary step of deciding that it is going to review the operations of the United Nations treaty committee system and its effects on Australia.

Madam Deputy Speaker, you will note, as I am sure you did, that there was a great deal of media commentary about this. I have here an article which was published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 31 March as an analysis piece by Michelle Grattan. It reads:

quote.para: The trouble for the Government with its decision to review its level of cooperation with United Nations committees is that it has the bad taste of sour grapes after an adverse judgment.

speech.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: Last weekend Attorney-General Daryl Williamsâ

speech.para: I note that the Attorney is in the chamberâ

quote.para: said the CERD committee's `international credibility will be in question unless it takes a more balanced perspective in the future'.

speech.para: Then Michelle Grattan observes, rather wryly:

quote.para: Unfortunately, Australia's international credibility is also on the line, and the government isn't helping it.

speech.para: It is also worth pondering the observations made by a former top ranking United Nations official who accused Australia of behaving like South Africa in other times. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 April, Mr John Pace is reported to have said that:

quote.para: ... the Federal Government's decision to review the way it deals with UN treaty bodies was `drastic'.

speech.para: The article also states:

quote.para: A former Australian diplomat who now heads the UN treaty section, Mr Palitha Kohona, also said he had never seen a statement like Mr Downer's ...

speech.para: the one to which I referred. It continues:

quote.para: `It is important to remember that criticism is not levelled for the sole purpose of criticising a country,' he told ABC radio.
`The criticism is levelled for the purpose of improving ... the human rights framework that is applicable to all countries in the world.'
`The ultimate loser will be the international human rights framework if a country were not to take such criticism seriously.'

Amnesty International said, `By criticising UN committees unfairly, the Howard Government is discrediting 55 years of hard work by Australian diplomats to build up a credible and effective UN treaty system.

speech.para: That is absolutely correct. Australia, historically, can be very proud of the role it has played, particularly in relation to this convention, particularly on this committee. We have done that because of our need and in the context of where we are in our history. I think a very important element of this is a recognition of our need to address the rights of indigenous Australians. Yet the government passes legislation which is arguably racially discriminatory and, because the United Nations makes observations about the possible discriminatory nature of that legislation, attacks the United Nations through one of its committees. It is all very well for the government to be parading on the international stage, saying how important we believe it is to recognise and acknowledge the needs of indigenous Australians and, in our domestically political environment, to talk about the need to acknowledge the importance of reconciliation. Why do they do this? Why can they not accept that there is a fair umpire elsewhere who may be able to make judgments which may in fact be truthful? The legislation before us is very important, but so is our international reputation. That international reputation has been quite severely sullied by the way the Australian government has dealt with the CERD committee.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank the members who have contributed to the debate on the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1999, specifically the members for Barton, Curtin, Lowe, Wentworth, Fowler and Northern Territory. Before summing up on the bill, I would like to briefly address the remarks made by the member for Northern Territory. He has made reference to Australia's obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the actions of the CERD committee in relation to a number of issues of indigenous policy in Australia. On three occasions, I think it is now, the CERD committee has effectively brought down a judgment about Australia, and its indigenous policies in particular respects, which the government regards as unbalanced and in fact an intrusion, unreasonably, into Australia's domestic affairs. The Commonwealth does take the deliberations of the committee and its obligations under the convention very seriously. This has been demonstrated on more than one occasion by the fact that the government has sent high-level delegations to attend hearings by the committee of Australia's periodic reports and to provide assistance to the committee in understanding those reports, but the government is seriously disappointed at the apparent failure of the committee to grapple with the unique and complex history of race relations in Australia. The committee has paid scant regard to the extensive material provided to it and has relied almost exclusively on material provided by non-government organisations.

speech.para: The review of the United Nations treaty committee system which the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced and to which the member for Northern Territory referred is an appropriate response to the actions of the CERD committee, but it is not only a response to that. For a considerable time, the government has expressed concern about the efficiency and effectiveness of the operation of the so-called United Nations treaty bodies, the committees established under treaties to which Australia adheres. Australia is not alone in expressing those concerns. Together with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I have been working since 1996 to foster constructive reforms to the operations of the treaty bodies and I have made representations in that regard to the United Nations High Commission for Human Rights and to the president of that organisation, Ms Mary Robinson. Other like-minded countries have similarly been working, including Canada, New Zealand and Norway.

The United Nations itself recognises that the treaty body system is in need of reform. It commissioned Professor Philip Alston to undertake a study. He has made at least three reports on the subject. Our review is a completely appropriate way of addressing our concerns, including the concerns of the way the government was treated by the CERD committee. The Australian people expect nothing less than a fair say in the international arena and the efficient functioning of the system. I reject the assertion by the member for Northern Territory, quoting Michelle Grattan, that Australia's international credibility is at risk in this respect.

As to the bill, it represents an appropriate and measured response to the decision of the High Court in Teoh's case. The High Court's decision gave treaties an effect in Australian law which they did not previously have. The government remains firmly of the view that this development is not consistent with the proper role of parliament in implementing treaties in Australian law.

Under the Australian Constitution, the executive government has the power to make Australia a party to a treaty, but it is for Australian parliaments to change Australian law to implement treaty obligations. The bill will restore the situation which existed before the Teoh caseâthat is, if there are to be changes to procedural or substantive rights in Australian law resulting from adherence to a treaty, they will result from parliamentary and not executive action. The bill is a clear application of the statement of the majority of the High Court in Teoh's case that a legitimate expectation, which it found to arise out of entry into a treaty by Australia, can be displaced by legislative action. Clause 5 provides that no legitimate expectation providing a basis at law for challenging an administrative decision can arise out of the fact that Australia is bound by an international instrument or the fact that an enactment reproduces or refers to the instrument.

As I noted in the second reading speech, it is unclear from the decision of the High Court whether state and territory administrative decisions may be the subject of legitimate expectations arising out of treaties. Clause 6 of the bill is intended to address that uncertainty. The bill will apply to state and territory decisions in those states and territories which have not taken their own legislative action to set aside legitimate expectations arising from treaties. Clause 6 of the bill does contain a roll-back provision which excludes the operation of the bill in relation to a state or territory administrative decision where the relevant state or territory legislature passes or has passed legislation having the same or similar effect as this bill. There should be no concern that the bill will affect the way in which treaties may otherwise have relevance in Australian law. It will not have such an effect. It will not, for example, impinge upon the operation of treaty provisions which have been incorporated into Australian law. This position is put beyond doubt by clause 7 of the bill. The government has acted appropriately and responsibly in bringing forward this bill. It is confined to addressing the decision in Teoh's case. It also complements the treaty reforms this government initiated on coming into office in response to criticisms that the Australian public did not have enough input into binding international treaties which touched upon an increasing array of national issues. One of the principal aims of those reforms was to enhance the role of parliament in scrutinising treaty action by the executive government.

Let me take the opportunity to remind you, Madam Deputy Speaker, that in July 1998 the government commenced its review of the landmark 1996 reforms of Australia's treaty making process in line with the commitment it made in 1996 to review the procedures after they had been in operation for two years. The report on the government's review of the treaty making process states that submissions to the review were overwhelmingly positive. The review marked the final stage of the reforms. These were a requirement to table treaties in parliament prior to binding action; the preparation of national interest analyses open to scrutiny by the public; the establishment of the parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties; the establishment of the Treaties Council comprising the Prime Minister, state premiers and chief ministers; and the establishment of the Australian treaties library on the Internet. The reforms have placed the Australian government in an excellent position to ensure that our national interests are met. The reforms also ensure that Australian interest groups can examine treaties and their likely effects and that interest groups are able to voice any concerns. The result is a more transparent process which gives Australians unparalleled input and an opportunity to understand the work of governments in making new international laws.

In contrast to the government's treaty reforms and its considered attempts to resolve the problem created by the decision in Teoh, the opposition has shifted and changed its position by supporting, then opposing and then proposing to amend the bill. The opposition has failed to support the bill despite the fact that it is largely the same as the bill it introduced when it was in government. Indeed, the member for Barton supported the bill in this place in 1997, noting that it was:

quote.para: ... appropriate to clarify the issue which arose in Teoh's case because having that issue floating around is itself something which is relied upon by those who oppose the legitimacy of the treaty making process.

speech.para: The then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the former member for Holt, stated soon after the Teoh decision was handed down by the court in 1995:

quote.para: I cannot help but regard this as anything other than a plainly bad decision. Teoh creates a decision making environment that is unworkable in practice.

speech.para: In fact, I think the former member for Holt was in the Senate at that time. The government agrees and is doing something to rectify that issue in the interests of the decision making.

The opposition has proposed an amendment to the bill. However, it appears to be the same as or similar to the statement that Senators Bolkus and McKiernan proposed in the amendment to the bill in their minority report in 1997. I reiterate the comments I made at that time, which are still relevant. The proposed amendment will create only more uncertainty and not remove it, as is claimed. To the extent that it actively encourages the courts to develop the common law on the basis of treaties, it will serve only to undermine the role of this parliament in legislating to give effect to treaties even further. In this respect, it should be noted that the amendment contemplates that the whole of the substance of a treaty could have effect by operation of the common law. This would have obvious consequences for the balance between the proper roles of the parliament, the executive and the judiciary. The amendment also fails to recognise that there are degrees of incorporation of international law in Australian law by statute. Giving international instruments the force of domestic law is but one of them. In addition, the wording of the principle as proposed by the opposition is totally unsuited for inclusion as an operative clause in the statute. Finally, it may have the effect of entrenching the operation of the Teoh doctrineâthat is, it could give the exact opposite effect to the bill as introduced by the government.

In summary, the amendment proposed by the opposition would create uncertainty rather than resolve it. It would entrench the Teoh doctrine rather than set it aside. It would serve to further undermine the proper role of the parliament rather than reinforce it. This bill is of great importance in stemming the tide of illegal immigration to Australia, a subject addressed by the member for Fowler. Many cases involving the application of the decision in Teohâindeed the Teoh decision itselfâinvolve attempts by persons whose presence in Australia is unlawful to delay their removal from Australia. The opposition's inconsistency on this bill smacks of hypocrisy of the highest order. The opposition supports the government's efforts to control the latest wave of unlawful entrants into Australia, yet by opposing the swift passage of this bill as introduced, as the opposition has done, the opposition ensures that those who do arrive and remain in Australia illegally will continue to be able to frustrate the government's efforts to remove them. I take some heart from the fact that the opposition has clearly understood the need for this bill in the past. I hope that it will abandon its latest hypocritical and politically opportunistic position on the bill and support its passage in its current form. I look forward to the passage of the bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Billâby leaveâtaken as a whole.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move opposition amendments Nos (1), (4) and (5):

quote.para: (1) Clause 5, page 3 (line 24) to page 4 (line 3), omit the clause, substitute:
(5) Legal effect of International instruments

It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Parliament that an international instrument (even though binding in international law on Australia) affects administrative decisions and procedures under domestic law only to the extent either that the instrument has the force of domestic law under an enactment or its substance has been incorporated into domestic law, in whole or in part, by the operation of the common law.
(4) Preamble, page 2, (lines 14-22), omit all the words from and including "On 10 May" to and including "any such legislative expectations".
(5) Preamble, page 2, (after line 22), at the end of the Preamble, add:

"Having considered the practical impact of the Teoh case, and the issues of principle involved, the Parliament of Australia believes that it is now necessary to reaffirm that an international instrument can have legal effect in Australian domestic law only to the extent that it is expressly incorporated by legislation, or its substance is incorporated into domestic law, in whole or in part, by the operation of the common law."

speech.para: I have moved these amendments in the context of the opposition being on record in this debate as supporting the thrust of this bill. Indeed, our voting has just occurred in favour of the second reading of the bill. It is wrong to suggest that in any way, shape or form the progress of this legislationâI might add that it is up to the government when it introduces it into the House and the Senateâcould influence the outcome of deportation orders or otherwise. In particular, in my speech on the second reading, I referred to the deportation guidelines, which specifically require the administrators to have regard, as a priority, to the rights of children involved. The Attorney might like to read my comments in that respect. It was worse than hypocrisy; it was opportunistic of him to even suggest that the position of the opposition in any way, shape or form restricts the deportation of criminals or illegal immigrants or otherwise. The facts of the matter are that the government's own guidelines specifically require their administrators to have regard in these circumstancesâas a primary issueâto the rights of the children, as was the outcome of the Teoh case.

Our amendments are, firstly, a specific statement of intention of the parliament consistent with the decision in Teoh's case and that stated intention is that international instruments do not have effect unless they have been incorporated into Australia's domestic law by enactment or unless they have been incorporated in whole or in part by the operation of the common law. That statement of intention ensures that parliament has the responsibility for enacting when international instruments applyâexcept in the third category, where the substance of an international instrument has specifically been incorporated into Australia's domestic law by virtue of a decision of a court in the development of the common law. With respect to the Attorney, he himself is quite ambiguous in the wording he uses, and we note his discussion of the operation of clause 7 of the bill, which the opposition accepts. Clause 7 says:

quote.para: To avoid doubt, section 5 does not affect any other operation, or use that may be made, of an international instrument in Australian law.

speech.para: According to the notes I made of the Attorney's speech, he acknowledged specifically that treaties can be incorporated into Australian law. If the Attorney is saying that treaties can be incorporated into Australian law only through an enactment of this parliament, he is wrong. The Attorney will be aware of the comments of the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Chief Justice Brennan, in Mabo and Others v. Queensland (No. 2) in which His Honour said:

quote.para: The opening up of international remedies to individuals pursuant to Australia's accession to the optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ... brings to bear on the common law the powerful influence of the covenant and the international standards it imports.

speech.para: There have been other instances where specific provisions of international instruments have been held to have been so significant that they have formed part of Australia's common law, and it is that situation that we are addressing. The specific failure of the government to address what they consider to apply in those circumstances itself leads to the uncertainty which the Attorney criticised. Far from creating uncertainty, we think our covering the situation of legislative enactment and also covering the incorporation of the substance of an international instrument into domestic law by virtue of a court decision as part of the development of the common law clarifies both situations, whereas the government will leave it quite ambiguous, which in itself is dangerous. (Extension of time granted)

To make our position clear, we are supporting the intention of the bill. The intention of the bill is to say that it is the responsibility of parliament to advise and instruct administrators on which international instruments they are required to have regard to in performing their administrative duties while at the same time recognising that in this country we have a system of developing common law. We sit on top of a living common law that has developed over 800 years, and the common law is as much a part of our legal system as any enactment from parliament. We heard, in the passage I have just read, of one instance where the High Court acknowledged that the provisions of international instruments can be incorporated into Australia's common law.

The common law, of course, develops by virtue of decisions of members of the judiciary by judges hearing cases. It is quite separate from and it does not apply to the Teoh decision, because in the Teoh decision the High Court held that as a matter of procedureâas opposed to substance of any particular treatyâadministrators were required to have regard to international instruments where the administrator determined that those international instruments gave rise to a legitimate expectation. We agree with the government that that outcome is quite inappropriate. Some 900 treaties have been ratified by Australia. It is quite unfair of and, indeed, poor administration on the part of any government to expect all administrators to be aware of the contents of all treaties. Indeed, those treaties themselves will in many areas have conflicting intentions or conflicting operations. Further, it is quite unfair and unrealistic to require administrators to then take another stepâto make their own determination as to whether a particular treaty gives rise to a legitimate expectation. Again, we are at one with the government in saying that it is the role of parliament to instruct administrators what treaties are to apply to their decision making process and in what way they are to apply to their decision making process.

The difference between what we are proposing and the outcome in Teoh is that point. The Teoh judgment said that, as a matter of procedure, administrators are required to have regard to all treaties for the purpose of going through that reasoning process which I have just described. We are saying emphatically that we regard that as inappropriate. In fact, it would be an abrogation of the responsibility of the parliament to allow that to continue to occur. However, in circumstances where a court has specifically stated that the substance of a treatyâthat is the terms of the treatyâhas been incorporated into Australia's common law, we say that administrators may be in a circumstance where, in applying the law, they will also be required to apply common law. Instances where the substance of a treaty has been incorporated in Australia's common law will be rare but, nonetheless, easily ascertainable by administrators having regard to decisions of judges of relevant Australian courts, which at a federal level would be the Federal Court and the High Court of Australia.

In summary, it is quite inappropriate for the government to suggest that the opposition is in any way attempting to fetter or restrain efficient administration. To the contrary, we want to clarify how administrators perform their role. We believe our amendments more precisely achieve that and for that reason we move those amendments 1, 4 and 5 as circulated in my name.

talk.start.para: âWhat the member for Barton said suggests that these amendments have been moved in good faith but, with respect, I think they are misconceived. The notion of incorporation into domestic law in the way that it is being used by the member for Barton is ambiguous, to say the least. To say that in moving these amendments the opposition supports the bill is really misleading. Opposition amendment 1 completely replaces the heart of the bill, that is, clause 5, with an amendment in the form of a statement of intention. This is highly uncertain in both its drafting and operation and it would be likely to entrench and compound the effects of the Teoh doctrine rather than overturn it. If the opposition were serious about resolving the longstanding problem created by the Teoh decision, they would have undertaken long ago to work with the government to find a workable solution, rather than shifting and changing positions at the last minute and introducing amendments without consultation.

speech.para: Opposition amendment 1 is substantially the same as the statement that Senators Bolkus and McKiernan proposed in their minority report of 1997. As I said earlier, the same concerns which arose in relation to that statement arise in relation to the opposition's amendment. The proposed amendment will only create more uncertainty, not remove it as is claimed. Secondly, to the extent that it actively encourages the courts to develop the common law on the basis of treaties, it will only serve to undermine even further the role of this parliament in legislating to give effect to treaties. In this respect it should be noted that the amendment contemplates that the whole of the substance of a treaty could have effect by operation of the common law. This would have obvious consequences for the balance between the proper roles of the parliament, the executive and the judiciary. I would add: it is not the present law. Thirdly, the amendment fails to recognise that there are degrees of incorporation of international law and Australian law by statute. Giving international instruments the force of domestic law, as the amendment proposes, is but one of them. The wording of the principle as proposed by the opposition is really unsuited for inclusion as an operative clause in a statute. It may have the effect of entrenching the operation of the Teoh doctrine. It could therefore have the exact opposite effect of the bill as introduced by the government.

The bill will not affect the use made by judges of international law, including treaties, as an influence on the development of the common law. This is made clear in clause 7 of the explanatory memorandum to the second reading speech. The bill, in fact, is intended to have a very narrow sphere of operation. Clause 5, the operative clause, is squarely directed towards displacing the legitimate expectation which the High Court found arose out of a treaty. It does not say that treaties can no longer be used in the development of the common law. In summary, amendment 1 proposed by the opposition would create uncertainty rather than resolve it. It would entrench the Teoh doctrine rather than set it aside and it would serve further to undermine the proper role of the parliament rather than reinforce it.

As to opposition amendment 4, which would omit reference in the preamble to the executive statements which have been made, the government believes that it is entirely appropriate to refer to these statements in the preamble. The government will not accept the omission of the relevant references. In the light of the comments I have made on opposition amendment 1, it will come as little surprise that the government will not support opposition amendment 5, as it simply foreshadows the opposition amendment to clause 5 in the same terms.
Amendments negatived.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move opposition amendments (2) and (3):

quote.para: (2) Preamble, page 2, (line 8), after 'Australian', insert 'domestic'.
(3) Preamble, page 2, (line 10), after 'Australian', insert 'domestic'.

speech.para: These amendments are simple amendments which apply in the preamble where there is a reference to Australian law. We feel that it would be, for the sake of clarity again, more appropriate to refer to Australian domestic law because the situation, as the wording currently exists, is `an international instrument by which Australia is bound or to which Australia is a party do not form a part of Australian law unless those instruments have been validly incorporated into Australian law by legislation'. We think it is appropriate to refer to domestic law to avoid a situation where the phrase could be construed as also implying international law. It is a fact that Australia is bound by virtue of international law to its international instruments and we believe the insertion of the word `domestic' to distinguish that situation is appropriate and hence the reason for our amendments.

talk.start.para: âThe government does not support these amendments. The references to Australian law in the preamble are clearly intended to refer to Australia's domestic law.

speech.para: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Williams)âby leaveâread a third time.
Bill returned from the Senate with an amendment.
Ordered that the amendment be taken into consideration at the next sitting.

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 2000

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: Fundamentally, the purpose of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 is:

to amend the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 to implement the 1996 Protocol to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter, 1972 (the London Convention); and

to amend the Sea Installations Act 1987 to remove the prohibitions on issuing, and varying, a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be located partly within and partly outside an adjacent area (which, generally speaking, is an area of Commonwealth waters adjacent to state coastal waters).

Indicative of the Commonwealth's commitment to the preservation of Australia's marine environment, the bill will also include a number of additional amendments to the sea dumping act that are intended to simplify, encourage compliance with, and the enforcement of, the sea dumping act.
Under the sea dumping act, Australia fulfils its obligations as one of 77 contracting parties to the London convention.

The London convention is aimed at promoting the effective control of pollution of the marine environment, by regulating the dumping of waste that is liable to: create hazards to human health; to harm living resources and marine life; to damage amenities; or to interfere with other legitimate uses of the sea.
It embodies a framework for regulating:
dumping into the seaâbased on a list of substances for which dumping is prohibited, and a list of substances requiring special care; and
incineration at seaâbased on incineration guidelines.
The London convention generally does not, however, apply in respect of:
vessels and aircraft entitled to sovereign immunity under international law;
the disposal of wastes or other matter derived from, or incidental to, the normal operations of a vessel, aircraft or platform; or
the disposal of wastes or other matter directly arising from, or related to, the exploration, exploitation and associated offshore processing of seabed mineral resources.
In summary, therefore, the sea dumping act currently regulates activities involving:
dumping into the sea;
incineration at sea; and
loading for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea;
where those activities occur either:
from, or on, a vessel, aircraft or platform, in, or above, Australian waters; or
from, or on, an Australian vessel anywhere at sea, or an Australian aircraft anywhere above the sea.
The proposed construction of artificial reefs is also assessed, and permitted, under the sea dumping act.
On 25 March 1998, Australia signed the 1996 protocol to the London convention, which entirely supersedes the London convention.

Under the protocol, contracting parties are obliged to take effective measures, according to their scientific, technical and economic capabilities, to reduce and where practicable eliminate pollution caused by the dumping into the sea, or the incineration at sea, of wastes or other matter.
The protocol embodies a more modern and comprehensive, and yet simplified, regulatory framework which aims to provide greater protection to the marine environment.
The protocol prohibits incineration at sea, except in an emergency situation, and outright prohibits the export of wastes or other matter for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea.
With respect to dumping, Annex 1 of the protocol provides a list of seven categories of wastes or other matter that may be considered for dumping at sea. These are:
dredged material;
sewage sludge;
fish waste, or material resulting from industrial fish processing operations;
vessels and platforms or other man-made structures at sea;
inert, inorganic geological material;
organic material of natural origin; and

bulky items, primarily comprising iron, steel, concrete and similarly unharmful materials, for which the concern is physical impact, limited to those circumstances where such wastes are generated at locations having no practicable access to disposal options other than dumping (for example, small islands with isolated communities).
Except for in an emergency situation, no other substances may be considered for dumping.

The general exemptions provided by the London convention, as I have outlined, are also incorporated in the protocol. As of 6 March 2000, there were eight contracting parties to the protocol. These were Denmark, the Republic of South Africa, the United Kingdom, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Republic of Vanuatu, the Kingdom of Spain, the Kingdom of Norway and the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Passage of this bill will implement the protocol nationally and satisfy Australia's domestic requirements for ratification. This action will reinforce the Commonwealth's commitment to the preservation of Australia's marine environment and reinforce Australia's standing as an international leader in responsible environmental management.
Additionally, the bill will revise the offence provisions in the sea dumping act in relation to:
dumping into the sea;
incineration at sea; and
loading for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea;
and will include new offences in respect of:
the export for dumping into the sea or incineration at sea; and
the unauthorised construction of artificial reefs.
A person engaging in activities constituting an offence against any of these revised or new offence provisions will be liable to a penalty of up to:

10 years imprisonment, a fine of 2,000 penalty units, which is approximately $210,000, or both, where the material involved in the commission of the offence includes seriously harmful materialâand note that seriously harmful material will include radioactive material and any other material prescribed by the regulation to be seriously harmful material;

two years imprisonment, a fine of 500 penalty units, approximately $55,000, or both, where the material involved includes non-Annex 1 material, and note that Annex 1 of the protocol, as I have outlined, lists the category of substances that may be considered for dumping under the protocol; and
one year imprisonment, a fine of 250 penalty units, approximately $27,500, or both, in any other case.

Corporations convicted of offences against these revised provisions will be liable, in accordance with the Crimes Act 1914, to up to five times these penalties. To ensure consistency between offence provisions in Commonwealth legislation, the bill will also apply chapter 2 of the Criminal Code to the offences under the sea dumping act.

Significantly, the bill will also put beyond doubt that the Commonwealth has the responsibility for regulating the construction of artificial reefs. In the past the legislative authority to do so has not always been certain. This bill will apply the sea dumping act to Australia's exclusive economic zone rather than, as is currently provided, the Australian fishing zone. As well, this bill will limit the current Defence Force exemption so that the Australian Defence Force will be required to comply with the act, except in an emergency situation or situation of armed conflict. The bill will also revise the exemption in relation to the naval, military or air forces of a foreign country in accordance with international law.

The bill will simplify the rollback provision, section 9, which authorises the minister administering the sea dumping act to make a declaration to limit the application of that act in respect of a state or the Northern Territory where that jurisdiction has enacted legislation to implement the protocol. Recognising that officers of the Australian Customs Service have the expertise and are generally well placed to assist in the enforcement of the provisions of the sea dumping act, this bill will also amend the act to include those officers as ex officio inspectors for the purposes of the sea dumping act. Finally, the bill will also include a number of amendments of a machinery nature designed to simplify the sea dumping act.

The Sea Installations Act was enacted to ensure that sea installations installed in adjacent areas are operated with regard to the safety of the people using them and of the people, ships and aircraft near them;
to apply appropriate laws in relation to such installations; and
to ensure that such installations are operated in a manner that is consistent with the protection of the environment.

A `sea installation' refers to any manmade structure that when in, or brought into, physical contact with the seabed, or when floating, can be used for an environment related activity. An environment related activity is defined to include any activity relating to:
tourism or recreation;
the carrying on of a business; or
the exploration and exploitation of the living resources of the sea, the seabed or the subsoil of the seabed.

The Sea Installations Act does not, however, generally include fishing installations; some exploration installations, such as installations and pipelines used by the petroleum industry; defence installations; or some cable installations. The act applies in respect of sea installations installed in an adjacent area of a state or affected territory which in general terms are the Commonwealth waters from three nautical miles out from the territorial sea baseline out to the outermost limits of Australian waters. The act does not apply in respect of sea installations located wholly within state coastal waters.
Under the Sea Installations Act, the lawful installation and operation of a sea installation will require either:
a permit to be issued;
an exemption certificate to be issued; or
a regulation to be made to exclude it from the application of the act.

At present the Sea Installations Act prohibits the issuing or varying of a permit that would authorise a sea installation to be located partly within and partly outside an adjacent area. There is also some doubt about the validity of issuing an exemption certificate to authorise such a sea installation. The bill will amend the Sea Installations Act to remove these permitting prohibitions. This will remedy the unworkable situation of, on the one hand, proposals falling within the scope of the Sea Installations Act and, on the other hand, that act not conferring sufficient powers upon the administering minister to regulate these same proposals.

In conclusion, passage of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000 will reaffirm Australia's commitment to the protection of the marine environment by implementing the 1996 protocol to the London convention. Passage of the bill will also strengthen the Commonwealth's power to ensure that all sea installations installed in an adjacent area are operated with regard to safety and in a manner consistent with the protection of the environment. It will do this by enabling permit conditions to also be imposed in respect of installations located both within and outside an adjacent area. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition supports and commends the aims of the Environment and Heritage Legislation Amendment Bill 2000. The bill implements the 1996 protocol to the London convention and increases penalties for contraventions of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act through amendments to the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 and the Sea Installations Act.
