talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice on 13 March 2000.

quote.para: (1) How many staff are employed in the Aged Care Complaints Resolution Unit in each State and Territory
(2) How many complaints is each unit investigating.
(3) How many complaint is each complaint officer investigating in each unit.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As at 1 March 2000 the Scheme employed 26 departmental officers located in the various State and Territory offices: NSW - 5, VIC - 6, QLD - 5, SA - 4, WA - 3, TAS- 1, ACT- 1, NT- 1.
There is addtional recruitment activity occurring particularly in New South Wales and Victoria.

(2) The Aged Care Complaints Resolution Scheme attempts to resolve complaints either through negotiation, mediation or determination. It does not conduct investigations of the type that may be undertaken by police or other appropriate agency.
As at 16 March 2Q00 the number of complaints being handled in each State/Territory was as follows - NSW - 150, VIC - 187, QLD - 90, SA - 26, WA - 25, TAS - 9, ACT - 8, NT - 0, Total - 495.
(3) The average number of complaints being handled by complaints officers in each State and Territory office is: NSW - 30, VIC - 3 1, QLD - 18, SA - 7, WA - 8, TAS 9, ACT - 8, NT -0.

In addition to these Departmental staff, the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency has established rapid response teams in each State which have the capacity to respond to urgent issues and conduct spot checks.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 15 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the speech by Dr Hawke to the National Press Club on 17 February 2000, when did he become aware the Department of Defence's financial position against the forward estimates was parlous and that Department's financial statements were in danger of being qualified by the Auditor-General.
(2) What action did he take to ensure that the integrity of the Commonwealth's finances were protected and what action is being taken to ensure they continue to be protected.
(3) Has he made, or will he make, any changes in the way his Department scrutinises the financial performance of the Department of Defence; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised that the Department of Defence's 1998-1999 audited financial statements were not qualified and that Defence is working with ANAO to address any issues raised in the audit.

(2) As my colleague the Minister for Defence has stated on a number of occasions, improving the management of Defence is a priority for Government. The Government will continue to seek improvements in the efficiency and accountability of the Department of Defence.
A team from the Department of Finance and Administration has been working full time with Defence to identify areas of improvement in financial management processes.

(3) The work of the joint team is ongoing. Any changes the Government makes will build upon our record of management improvements so that the taxpayer can be confident their money is well spent and that the Australian Defence Force is fully capable of meeting is mission.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: New Children's Hospital, Westmead
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1295)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 4 April 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware that the New Children's Hospital at Westmead raises approximately 11% of its annual running costs from community fund raising activities such as selling clip-on bears on Bandaged Bear Day.

(2) Is he aware of the hospital's concerns that the GST will either have to be added to the $3 donation usually given in exchange for a bear, or be absorbed into the $3 donation, thus losing 30 cents per donation.
(3) Will the Government collect GST through these types of fund raising activities; if not, how will such activities be exempted from the tax.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) I am aware that the Hospital has sought clarification on the GST treatment of donations given in exchange for a clip-on bear.

(3) The President of the New Children's Hospital has advised that the bears cost $0.54 each, and that persons purchasing the bears for $3.00 do not intend to purchase an item worth $3.00 but rather are making a donation to the work of the hospital. Other examples of items of insubstantial value that have the nature of a receipt are things like red noses and daffodil pins.
In these circumstances, the supply of the bears will be in the nature of a receipt and will not be subject to GST.

subdebateinfo.title: Financial Management and Accountability Act: Act of Grace Payments
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1447)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 13 April 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many requests for act of grace payments under section 33 of the Financial Management and Accountability Act have been considered by his delegate since the Act came into force.
(2) How many requests have (a) been approved and (b) not been approved.
(3) How many of the requests which have not been approved have chosen to provide additional information for him to review the decision, and of these, how many have been approved subsequently.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Delegates have considered 248 requests for act of grace payments under section 33 of the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997(the FMA Act)since it came into force on 1 January 1998 to the date the honourable Member asked his question on 13 April 2000.
(2) (a) Of the 248 requests received:
. 110 were approved;
. 2 had a proportion of the amount requested approved; and
. 46 requests were referred to other Departments (as the matters came within the parameters of compensatory mechanisms other than the act of grace provisions of the FMA Act).
(b) 90 were not approved.

(3) In 19 cases of claims not approved, claimants sought a review of the initial decision on the basis of additional information or changes in circumstances. There were no subsequent approvals as a result of these reconsiderations.
